Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Equatorial Internal Gravity Wave Shear, Strain, Instabilities and Mixing--A Moored Process Study
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the physics of instabilities that lead to the unique strong turbulent flux below the equatorial cold tongue is an imperative step toward developing a physics-based turbulence parameterization for improving the model prediction of the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) phenomenon. The primary goal of this experiment is to make long-term observations of detailed evolutions of internal waves, instabilities, and mixing at time scales from 1-min to months and at vertical scales from 0.5 m to O(100) m below the equatorial cold tongue. The tongue of cold water straddling the equator in the eastern Pacific is one of the major sea surface temperature (SST) features influencing tropical air-sea interactions. Vertical turbulent fluxes through the base of the surface mixed layer are major factors in the heat budget that determines SST. Strong turbulence during La Nina cools the mixed layer, strengthening the cold tongue. Weak turbulence during El Nin1 allows the mixed layer to warm, weakening or erasing the cold tongue. Several periods of intensive microstructure profiling discovered the role of small-scale mixing in modulating the cold tongue, but attempts to parameterize the turbulent fluxes failed because the physics leading to instabilities and turbulence has not been captured by these measurements. Previous observations indicate that internal waves play the key role by providing the finescale shear that trigger instabilities. High spatial and temporal resolutions of measurements, sufficiently capturing instabilities below the cold tongue, are needed, but have not been made.

In the present experiment, shear and strain will be measured at 1-minute intervals over vertical scales of O (1-100) m and turbulent scalar diffusion rates immediately beneath the surface mixed layer in the cold tongue. Co-investigators Moum and Nash at OSU have recently developed a moored microstructure package that can reliably measure turbulent scalar diffusion rates in the equatorial undercurrent. Closely vertically spaced instruments measuring velocity, temperature, salinity and mixing rates will be mounted on a surface mooring. The mooring will be 5 miles from the long-term TAO mooring at 0 140 W. The experiment will be coordinated with another funded observational program. In spring 2008, 10 pods, evenly spaced between 30 and 90-m depth, will be deployed on the long-term TAO mooring at 0 140 W. The deployment will be Immediately with18 days of shipboard microstructure profiler measurements.

Intellectual Merit.
Internal waves produce much of the diapycnal mixing in the ocean and must be understood and quantified before accurate mixing parameterizations can be developed. In the eastern equatorial Pacific, the stratified high-shear zone between the undercurrent core and the base of the mixed layer provides a unique environment for internal waves. Understanding it well enough to accurately parameterize the diapycnal mixing is a major intellectual challenge whose solution will advance the general understanding of internal waves, instabilities, and turbulence, as well as provide necessary support for climate studies.

Broader Impact
This work is expected to lead to more accurate parameterizations of equatorial mixing in general circulation models (GCM) and thus to more realistic climate models. SST, air-sea interaction, and ENSO in the cold tongue are strongly controlled by the turbulence entrainment flux. To improve the large-scale model prediction of ENSO, we need to understand the physics of instabilities and turbulence and improve the turbulence parameterization in GCMs. The proposed project will provide support for the education of a graduate student. The observations and analysis results will be published on a publicly accessible website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ocean’s capacity to store heat and influence global climate is controlled at the most fundamental level by heat transport through the air-sea interface. The Pacific equatorial cold tongue is a region of large net ocean heat uptake. Changes in global climate due to anthropogenic influences may be strongly influenced by the dynamics of the equatorial ocean because of the strong transports there. One of the most difficult aspects of forecasting resultant future climates is proper parameterization of the ocean’s mixing, which in turn is made difficult by the lack of an adequate observational base. The primary objectives of the work done with funding from this grant were:

  • to obtain a comprehensive time series at 0, 140W that includes currents, stratification and turbulence measurements using proven profiling technology;
  • to compare these measurements to those obtained using χpods that have been newly-developed to significantly improve our observational data base of equatorial mixing.  χpods were deployed on the Tropical Atmosphere-Ocean (TAO) mooring at 0, 140W and an additional high-resolution mooring deployed specifically for this experiment; and
  • to use these measurements to relate mixing and internal wave (shear instability) activity as a critical step toward improving mixing parameterizations.

This successfully-executed experiment provides an important data base from which (to date) three significant results ensue. These are listed below

  1. 1.      χpods as a quantitative measure of mixing on equatorial moorings

Direct comparisons of turbulence quantities were made from from thermistors on χpods at several depths on the two equatorial moorings separated by 10 km and from thermistors and shear probes on our turbulence profiler, Chameleon. These comparisons between completely independent measurements from Chameleon and χpods on the two moorings indicates that mean values of χT and εχ (over 16 days) agree to better than a factor of 2. They reproduce both the large magnitudes of χT and εχ  above 100 m and the 2 orders of magnitude decrease in ε below. Further analysis suggests that differences on shorter timescales can be reasonably accounted for by natural variability between measurement locations.

  1. 2.      Discovery of the huge contribution of tropical instability waves (TIWs) to equatorial mixing

Temporal variations in mixing are driven by large-scale dynamics with long and/or intermittent periodicity. At a fixed location, mixing rates vary by many orders of magnitude on short and long timescales.  Significantly, a series of shipboard experiments in the central equatorial Pacific that began in 1984 revealed variability in mixing associated with the daily heating cycle, shear instabilities and Kelvin waves. But it was not until 2008 that the dominating contribution to sea surface cooling via mixing of cool fluid from below associated with TIWs was quantified by us during this experiment. The TIW-enhanced shear acted to elevate turbulence mixing by nearly 10 times that observed during non-TIW periods at the same site and season. The turbulence heat flux in the upper 90 m was 400 Wm-2, almost ten times that observed in previous experiments without TIWs and three times greater than the surface heat flux. Long-term (23 years) correlation of TIW kinetic energy with annual SST cooling suggests that TIWs contribute significantly to SST cooling via their contribution to subsurface mixing. This result counters previous analyses that suggested TIWs heated the equatorial sea surface by advection.
